title: K and p conservation in collision

content.question: Two ideal gas molecules with identical masses travel toward each other as shown in the figure. Molecule <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has an initial velocity of <math alttext="2 v sub 0 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to the right and molecule <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has an initial velocity of <math alttext="v sub 0 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to the left. The molecules collide head-on. Which of the following claims correctly describes their motion after the collision?

choices.label: The molecules must have velocities in opposite directions to conserve momentum.
The molecules must have velocities in opposite directions to conserve kinetic energy.
Momentum is conserved because the collision is assumed to be elastic.
Determining the magnitudes of their velocities includes applying conservation of kinetic energy because the collision is assumed to be elastic.

content.answer: Determining the magnitudes of their velocities includes applying conservation of kinetic energy because the collision is assumed to be elastic.
